reviews:
Having lived in California for 56 years and traveled the coast almost annually, we've been to many of the missions. San Juan Capistrano is probably the most well-known because of the swallows and also the most beautiful since it's an active church that was majestically rebuilt. Carmel Mission is the burial site of St. Junipero Serra and Sonoma Mission in the Sonoma Plaza is the northernmost.

But Mission Santa Barbara resting high atop the city of Santa Barbara is probably the most important for its grounds and the fact that it is the home mission for the Franciscan Friars. We've been to the mission many times but never took the docent tour until April of 2017. The 1-2 hour tour (small fee) is well-worth the effort. The docents are well-versed in the history of the missions, the grounds are incredibly well-kept, the church and associated buildings are well-preserved, and the views are spectacular. Great history.

IMAGINE you are one of the Monks treking the length of California in the 1700-1800's, dependent on reaching one of the Missions for replenishment and safety. From San Diego to Northern CA, Missions were built to establish communities several days apart, as the Monks established settlements across the state. The Santa Barbara Mission and El Presidio were the first significant buildings in Santa Barbara, supporting each other as the community grew. Walk the same tiles as early settlers, see remnants of the successful aquaduct from the Mission back into the foothills of the Botanic Garden; walk around the early water cistern still functional across from the Mission; and discover the inner Mission courtyard, a Memorial to those that came before us. Be delighted with the fantastic ocean view from the steps of the chapel. This Mission is a keep sake, cherished, alive and serving its community still.

If you are a visitor to California, make sure you stop here before you leave. Tourists here for Disney, the beaches, Hollywood, etc will miss out on a part of California that was here before the first tourist attractions. The Santa Barbara mission is one of the many mission churches that Spanish missionaries founded in the 1700s and 1800s. The museum does a very good job of handling the situation between the indigenous people who were here, and the missionaries. The missionaries brought knowledge and faith from Europe and the local people taught the missionaries about the land and local food sources. The beautiful church and grounds have withstood earthquakes, fires, floods, etc over the years. If you are Catholic, there is Mass there every day.

A visit to California is not complete without a visit to one of the missions established in the late 18th century. The missions remain a controversial institution. However, history points to the fact that Native Americans were enslaved to the Spanish mission system. The story of Native Americans in California and the role of the missions is sad, and I felt the museum here paints a somewhat accurate picture but not entirely. Still, the missions existed and remain and so does our native Chumash community. I would like to see more inclusion of the Chumash culture at the mission. The fact that the mission is so beautiful shows the artistic prowess and dedication of the Native Americans who actually built and decorated the missions and were an integral part of them. The mission presents a good place to think about and consider this and to contemplate imperialism, exploitation, racism, and the role of faith in all of this in the past and today.

The mission church and the attached graveyard are the highlights. The colours inside the chapel are golden and warm, and the history on the gravestones is incredible.

Of course, the whole place exists on the basis of invasion by European nations and to say that the mission is built on the bones of the native inhabitants is both figuratively and realistically true. There are, apparently, hundreds, if not thousands, of unnamed native inhabitants buried in unnamed graves in the graveyard.

Make the time to visit. It is as old as anything you will find in California.

It is good to understand what a museum is all about. Mission Santa Barbara was a mission by the Spanish Franciscans. The establishment of this mission was before California became part of the US in 1786. In 1790, the first buildings were put up.

According to the stories, the original purpose of the mission was the Christianization of the Chumash Indians. However, the Mexican government secularized the mission.

When California became part of the United States, the mission was turned back to the Catholic Church in 1865. In 1812 a large earthquake destroyed the church. The final restorations, after the following 1925 earthquake, were done in 1953.

We made this mission our last stop on what otherwise was an amazing 2-day “missions” trip because it was the “queen” of the mission, but we were very disappointed.
1. There is an ugly mini-mall style parking lot filled with cars right at the door step of the mission church and all along the front of the mission. Talk about pulling down paradise and putting up a parking lot! Not a welcoming nor attractive entrance to the “queen” of the missions.
2. Once we got through the ugly parking lot, we tried to get into the mission grounds. We were there around 4:30, and were told that the last tour left at 4:15, and we were not going to be permitted to enter the grounds. The website is not clear, and only stated tour times. Otherwise it seemed the missions was open until 5:15pm. We did not want a tour, so the last tour leaving at 4:15 seemed like it should not be a problem. But it was. I asked if we can just pay and quickly take a few pictures. Answer – No! Why? I guaranteed them we would be out in 10 mins. Still No!
3. So we figured we would salvage the trip here and at least go into the mission church before the mission closes. Wrong again. There was a mass from 4 to 5 and we were not permitted to even enter the church. I get it this is a church, but make mass from 5 to 6 when you are not supposedly welcoming guests to see the place. This seemed like a poor selection to have a service time. Perhaps a little consideration for the folks who have driven hundreds of miles to see the place would be nice. Starting mass at 5 instead of 4 would be nice for those visitors. But do they care?
So after going through an ugly parking lot, being told no we can not even take pictures of the grounds even though there were lots of people still in the grounds, and not being able to even go into the church, we left. I love the Rose Garden down across the lawn in front of the Old Mission. It is planted with so many different varieties of roses, in so many different shapes, sizes and colors, all in little clumps so you can see several of the same type of rosebush.

In colder climes, roses might bloom only in summer. Here in Santa Barbara they bloom all year round, except for in January and February - and that is because a day of Community Rose Pruning is held there in January, in which people can come and learn the right way to prune roses. By March or so, the blossoms are back, and the roses just keep on blooming until the following January when the plants get pruned again.

The Old Mission has so many more attractions, too. I think it is one of the best places to visit in Santa Barbara. The Mission is a beautiful place to visit on the outside, day or night, with lovely soft illumination all night long. Outside there is a lovely fountain, a historic water trough where people used to come to wash their clothes, and nice views out over Santa Barbara to the ocean and islands beyond. On the inside you can take a self-guided tour that takes you to many parts of the interior, the central garden, the sanctuary, and the old graveyard.

The steps of the Mission are a gathering place at certain times of the year, particularly at the sidewalk chalk art festival I Madonnari on Memorial Day Weekend, at the Fiesta Pequena on the Wednesday before Fiesta (always held the first weekend in August), and at Christmas, when a manger is erected outside in front of the Mission.

Of course you can also attend Mass at the sanctuary here, all year round.

It was founded by Padre Fermín Lasuén on December 4, 1786, the feast day of Saint Barbara, as the tenth mission for the religious conversion of the indigenous local Chumash-Barbareño tribe of Native American people. If you are visiting the Santa Barbara area, stop and see the Living Old Mission and Museum and take the Garden Tour (on your own or with a docent) which is operated by the Franciscan Friars. The Mission is beautiful and is in great repair. The walking tour takes about an hour on your own and includes the Sacred Gardens, the video room where one can watch a brief but very informative video of the making of the mission and the history of the area, cemetery, the church (which has amazing artwork), the Museum, The Fountain and the Aqueduct and of course the gift shop. Make sure you wear appropriate clothing for visiting a church and very comfortable shoes as the grounds are a bit irregular and rough in places. No pets are allowed and neither is flash photography. There is limited handicap access. One of the most interesting things that I learned is that the book, "Island of the Blue Dolphin" is based on a true account written by one of the friars of a girl who was left behind by her people for almost 18 years and survived on her own until she was rescued and brought to the Mission where she lived out her days and is buried there. I would highly recommend touring here. As a side note, outside and to the left of the parking lot there is a picnic area and a Meditative Olive Garden Pathway one can walk if one is so inclined and Stations of the Cross. The La Huerta Historic Gardens can only be accessed by calling and making a reservation.
